commentBody: A proper Saturday workout.

Good day to be a Nintendo fan. BOWSER and KOOPATROOPA were nice gimmes, and OCARINAS I never would have gotten without knowing the Zelda game. Breezy 18 minute solve. Really the only thing that slowed me down was taking way too long to correct RuCKus to RACKET.

And I so wanted 18D to by Yoshino. All I had was the second letter being an O, I didn't even check the length before typing it in

I have spent no time TODATE in the Mario universe, 
but handy crosses let me say WEREDONE 
without going KABLOOEY.
No CARPS from me. 

Thanks for the RIDE, Jesse.
Loved it. Perfect Saturday workout. Kablooey always reminds me of Calvin and Hobbes, my all-time favourite comic strip.
Love today's photo. That would have been something to see.
Could someone explain 40 across?

"Look at how we're packaging these playing cards!"
"Well, that seals the deal!"

(These puns suit me just fine.)

Not quite stacks, but the staggered long entries both vertical and horizontal (cascades?) evoked a nice story for nice. 

This is my favourite type of themeless puzzle, hands down. 

DAISYCHAINS
KOOPATROOPA
TOURDEFORCE
A floral prize for someone who just beat a Super Mario game in record time. No ASTERISK required. 

SANTATRACKER
SEALEDTHEDEAL
CAMERALENSES
The story of a smug kid who managed to catch of early glimpse of their Christmas presents ny spying on Santa‚Äôs sled with their homemade telescope.
Can someone explain the "most likely to succeed"=SOONEST?  Thank you
Tough and chewy...a perfect Saturday challenger

I smiled at 1A because when my grandson was visiting last week, I helped (well actually watched) him build a Lego set of BOWSER  driving a muscle car.  Through him, I was also familiar with BOWSER‚Äôs minions, KOOPATROOPAs.  Despite these serendipitous gimmes, the rest of the puzzle was a stop and go affair that I completed a bit at a time, with the middle remaining incomplete until I SEALEDTHEDEAL by figuring out shook hands was SEALEDTHEDEAL.

I wrote a long description of my struggles with the puzzle, stuff about acing the NW corner (OCARINA jumped right out) and expecting the rest not to be too tough, but I needed the column for CELINE instead of JoLinE, and IDeals instead of IDYLLS, got the KOOPA from the crosses but never heard of the TROOPAS. I'm having trouble getting used to the new regime but this time I remembered to I copy my comment before I went back to the column, but then . . .copied Jesse's name and overrode it.  Aaaaargh! I finished it, but no self-congratulation celebration this time.

And Jesse, were you trying to frighten us with your alert that we will have another from you "soon"?  I will admit that this was a very classy, worthy Saturday puzzle, but I'm hoping that your next one will be a Monday.

I'm not sure if I'm allowed to comment on the Mini puzzle here or if there is a place to comment on it? The clue for 5 across "Catering container containing caffeine" uses alliteration well. It also reminds me of the mnemonic to remember the first 10 digits of pi "May I have a large container of coffee? Thank you." 3.141592653

I see you, Mario ‚Äî but I‚Äôm here to give a shout out to Zelda.  OCARINA of Time is one of the best video games ever made.

And, assuming most of you are not Nintendo aficionados, I double-dog dare you to buy a Switch and play Zelda - Breath of the Wild and tell me it isn‚Äôt a masterpiece. 

You can thank me later. 

In the mean time, I‚Äôll thank Jesse Guzman for a great Saturday puzzle.

I have to say I‚Äôm a little disappointed. Too straightforward for my taste for a Saturday, despite the fact that I needed most of the crosses for the Mario Brothers characters. I think I was 7 when the game came out? I know this is supposed to be the kind of stuff that you remember 40 years later (my husband does), but I just don‚Äôt. 

DAISY CHAINS made me smile. We went to a midsummer‚Äôs eve celebration last week and had a great time. Both of us got rather elaborate versions of daisy chain wreaths for our heads and, yes, we did dance around the bonfire. When in Rome, etc. 

Have a good weekend, everyone.
Thank you to NYT puzzle makers. The more frustrating and taxing the better to keep my sanity from the insanity of reality right now.

Most likely to tear my hair out and howl at the moon! You can bet your flyspecking swatter there was more time added for a good solid cuss and a "what the heck...?" to boot. Saturday smatterday. Sheesh.

Good gravy, that clue stretched my last nerve.

Moderately scary for me.  I don't play video games and at least one here was a deep cut.  Never heard of California Angelica.  I had trouble in most of the quadrants, except lower right.

Enjoyed seeing Kablooey though.  Reminds me of Spaceman Spiff and the Gooey Kablooey.  Deer stalking aid was a pretty poor clue.
I set my Saturday PB‚Ä¶ and I finished faster than Friday, or Thursday, or Wednesday. I got really lucky that basically everything I plugged in the grid ended up working.

Way too hard for me to finish, despite not being trivia-heavy. This is not a complaint, simply a fact. I'm leaving the grid 1/3 empty and moving on. Even with autocheck on I finally found myself unable to make any further progress - I refuse to pick random letters until something sticks, and I have no educated guesses left to try.

The clues were not simply not on my wavelength - they seemed to have arrived from another time-space continuum altogether. I also did not understand many clues and/or answers. For example, I have no idea what a "full RIDE" may be. As is usually the case, none of my unknows are elaborated upon in the column, either, except for ANGELICA (one of my lookups today).

Another lookup: KOOPATROOPA... Sigh. I've been a video gamer for almost 40 years now but I've never played a Nintendo game and I know next to nothing about them. That name looks so silly it borderline triggers me ü§£ (ditto the unfamiliar KABLOOEY). It does not help that KOOPA would be transcribed as kupa in Polish, and that means poop...

Polish trivia time! In Warsaw folklore, the layer of golden eggs is a duck.

Both 33D ‚ÄúMost likely to succeed?‚Äù = SOONEST and 40A ‚ÄúCrushing, in a way‚Äù = MOONY don‚Äôt make sense to me. 

I can sort of get that having a crush on someone means you are mooning over them, but it seems a stretch even for a Saturday. Maybe it‚Äôs generational or regional?  So far, even though I‚Äôve read a few ideas posted here (as of 12:47 am NY time), I can‚Äôt convince myself of anything to make sense of SOONEST.  

I‚Äôm U.S. born and have lived here almost my entire life. I pity our non-U.S. solvers on these clues. 

I enjoyed the Marioverse clues even though I know almost nothing about that game. They took me down a rabbit hole that led me to learn that a local Seattle-area guy was the inspiration for Mario and I‚Äôm pretty sure I went to school with his daughter!

l had to work around not knowing anything about Mario or his universe, and that was tough -- two nonsensical answers (one long). Now that I know a couple of charcters from Mario, I'm gonna forget them ASAP.
Really struggled to connect with this one. The cluing just didn't do it for me.

What a pleasant solve for a rainy Saturday morning! It wasn‚Äôt that hard but still gave me a good workout in places. I was delighted to see 1A and 16A, they took me right back to childhood. I got 1A immediately, but had to rattle the old brain for a while to remember 16A. I love finding out the odd bits and bobs of information my brain has retained, like in this case the real name of the turtle guys. A word I‚Äôve definitely not used in decades.

Wow, a workout for me but engrossing.  Loved finally getting OCARINAS .  Some of the constructor's Gimmes were simply not available to my 1am brain. (Duh, 5-letter state ending in "ine"?). 
I couldn't let go of "hOrNY" for [Crushing]  until I gave in and got the crossing ....TROOPA from the column.  Oh well, I thought it was clever.

OCARINAS was a nice and assumed intentional tie-in to the Nintendo ecosystem, even if it isn‚Äôt from the Mario universe with the cross of BOWSER..

For those not aware, 1998‚Äôs The Legend of Zelda; The Ocarina for the Nintendo 64 console is considered by many to be the best game in the nearly 40 year-old Zelda franchise. In fact, to this day OOT (as it is known) is still in the conversation for the best video game of all time across all genres, franchises, and consoles.

Humming Epona‚Äôs Song in my head right now. It will be with me well into the morning.

In a parliamentary example of two countries separated by a common language, in British English  ‚Äúto TABLE a motion‚Äù means to present it for immediate consideration (ie. putting it on the table for all to see).

Arrgh mateys! A fine puzzle. For indeed it were a hearty mystery in need o' solvin'! But solve it I did. Me pencil working like a cutlass through a boarding party. I ain't had that much fun since my last keel haulin'! Arrgh!

A slog. 

Still baffled by MOONY 

Wouldn‚Äôt a TOUR DE FORCE get 5 stars?

Thanks

This is my favorite type of puzzle: one that I initially despair of solving‚Äîthat nevertheless comes in below my average time for its day of the week. I remembered enough of the Marioverse from my kids‚Äô involvement back in the day to get BOWSER immediately, but after that it seemed that I stared blankly at an empty grid for quite some time before making any progress. But I persevered and managed to get to the music! 
I, however, only got SOONEST through crosses, and like others here, could not make sense of the clue; I still think this 
was not so much cleverly deceptive as unpleasantly stretchy. MOONY, however, I thought was perfect Saturday misdirection, although its meaning did at first elude me!
Can someone explain GOOSE? Having a bit of trouble understanding it

Always a delight to get a tough Saturday with fun Fridayish clues like ‚ÄúDeer stalking aid?‚Äù and ‚ÄúThey focus on subjects of interest.‚Äù Also, while I will defend crossword glue to the death, a puzzle virtually devoid of it, like this one, is a thing of beauty. Hope all are well. I miss this wonderful Wordplay community but find myself becoming peevish on here too often, and a peevish Puzzlemucker is not easy to live with. So I‚Äôve been keeping some polite but bittersweet distance. Here‚Äôs my favorite song about DAISY CHAINS: https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=Eg4yoCxqCCs
Excellent Saturday outing, thank you Jesse G. And I am here to attest that yes you can complete this puzzle without knowing anything about the Mario universe.  Because I did and I don't.
Great puzzle!
Midsummer head decorations is wrong, no one wears daisy chains it‚Äôs flower crowns
Thank you, Jesse. Much to enjoy, 16A a cracker. Haven't heard that term for years.

I know nothing about video games but I knew what an OCARINA was from its starring role in the haunting theme music to "The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly". I was surprised though, because I wouldn't think of it as light. The only one I ever saw and heard played was made of something like ceramic and was very loud.
How I finished this puzzle, I'll never know and I did it in 6% less time than average. So many unknowns.

Was very surprised when I entered the final K of Kablooey and got the gold star. Enjoyable puzzle but there were a couple of clues that I just don't get. Tour de force - why four stars specifically? And soonest - something to do with line of succession? Doesn't quite work for me but might be missing something
I had coP for ‚Äúit can keep the beat‚Äù and I thought that was clever but I was cleverly wrong.

Ahh, a Saturday puzzle to sink my teeth into. The feeling of thinking "Uh oh, I might not get this one." and then teasing it out is what I'm here for. Thanks, Jesse. [Most likely to succeed?] for SOONEST and [Deer stalking aid] for SANTA TRACKER were groaners in the best possible way. Solvers around my age may be familiar with the OCARINA from The Troggs "Wild Thing": https://youtu.be/e6uXWcWtO7I?si=9G5f6SFItbMnsJcT
You don‚Äôt want an ICEPOP to become SOUPY, best to consume it PRONTO.

This was fun. A little more than half of my Saturday average, so we were definitely connecting.

Back in the late 80's? early 90's? a Nintendo Christmas gift for my kids led to me spending many hours playing Mario Brothers, Tetris, and other games. I rescued the princess in the original Mario Brothers, kept winning in Tetris until there were no more levels to conquer (didn't weep), but the most I ever got out of Zelda was the great game music. Still, it took a while to recall BOWSER (which could have also been clued as [Sha Na Na singer].

Got stalled but never stymied in the lower right corner. Once I got RENO and CELINE the rest of the pieces fell into place.

Great start to the weekend. Thanks!
My streak of checking for a word is alive at 1,286 games. I‚Äôm rolling now.

Whew. Typical tough Saturday workout for me, and had to look up some things, but ended up being an enjoyable workout.  Lots of nice 'aha' moments when I finally had enough crosses for something to dawn on me. And... the app finally let me actually log in to solve it so I'm back on a one day streak. 

And... one of my all time favorite songs at 31d. That will probably be stuck in my head (enjoyably) for quite a while. 

Puzzle find today was a fairly recent one, but of course I didn't remember it. I'll put that in a reply. 

...

A great, chewy Saturday. Enough to make my brain sweat, but not impossible.
Knowing nothing about Mario; my kids were never into it, held me up a while, but the crosses slowly got me there. I took a punt on KABLOOEY once I had LOOEY. Delighted to find it was correct. 
There are a few clues/answers that I didn‚Äôt quite understand (MOONY, TOUR DE FORCE, SOONEST), but they‚Äôve been discussed in earlier posts, so I‚Äôm a little wiser now.

It‚Äôs horrendously humid today. If any of you are watching the Glastonbury festival later, you‚Äôll see. I expect they‚Äôll be turning the hoses on the crowd come mid afternoon to cool them down. It‚Äôs going to be a sweat box in the Hall for the village barn dance tonight (slightly different tunes to Glasto!) I‚Äôll  be a gin soaked puddle by the end as I‚Äôm manning the bar.
No naticks. Challenging. No awkward fill or clues. Great puzzle.

Just looking at comments, I see two entries that people don‚Äôt particularly like. My thinking is that the time that is most likely to succeed (in the sense of ‚Äúfollow on from‚Äù) this moment is the next moment (which is the SOONEST). Maybe? It made sense to me while I was filling it in, in any case. And if you‚Äôre crushing on someone, you will be MOONY. Anyway this was very near a PB solve time for me; I was absolutely on this constructor‚Äôs wavelength (but I accept that I‚Äôm pretty weird).

I remember listening to the kids in the other room playing Mario Karts while I made dinner, over 20 years ago. Somehow after the third or fourth pass through, Bowser just came to the front of the dusty attic of my brain. Got Kablooey  looking at a string of letters and thought it sounded like something from the game. Those were the two most satisfying moments of the solve. That middle of this thing were killer for me.

Well, Jesse, you had me at DAWDLED over KABLOOEY.  At that point, you didn‚Äôt have to pad the goodies.  But you did:

‚Ä¢	Crossing triple stacks with no ugly crosses, and with five of the six answers pulsing with verve.  Wow!
‚Ä¢	Saturday-worthy clues taking a set of mostly commonly-known words, and hiding them in mystery.
‚Ä¢	A grid design free of scattershot black squares, lovely to look at, and first time ever in the Times.
‚Ä¢	The high-level skill to make an uber-low 66-worder ‚Äì look at all those chunks o‚Äô white! ‚Äì so clean.

And, Jesse, you have a chance to make crossword history.  Only one constructor (Andrew Ries) has hit the cycle (a puzzle for every day of the week) in their first seven NYT puzzles, but none has done it with the seven days in order.  Your first three puzzles are TH, FR, SA ‚Äì Go for it!

In any case, in just three puzzles you‚Äôve shown you have The Knack, that ability to craft first class crosswords.  Please don‚Äôt be a stranger, and thank you for a splendid outing today!

Well, um‚Ä¶

Yesterday I requested more
of a challenge, after shoving
a late-week brain into my head,
so the solve would be arduous 
and ultimately,
satisfying.

KABLOOEY!

Not the correct usage of that word,
but I don‚Äôt care.

I‚Äôll keep this one short 
cuz I gotta pick the grit and gravel from my teeth.

Then send a tacit text to my kids
thanking them for the *three* letters
I got today from their D and D phase
(as though that ever really ends)
and reprimanding them for skipping
the *entire* flippin‚Äô Mario world.

Kids are so selfish.

Thank you Jesse!
I will happily await the next!

Happy weekend all!
"Deer stalking aid?" might be the funniest clue I've ever seen. Well done.

An annoying misspelling! How did this get past the editors? It's not KABLOOEY; it's KABLOOie! As in "Hamster Huey and the Gooey KABLOOie" of Calvin and Hobbes fame. https://www.reddit.com/r/calvinandhobbes/comments/1bi6ok7/i_want_hamster_huey/ I hope no one is going to suggest that Bill Watterson has been leading me astray all these years!

Oh - one more late comment. I went and looked at Mr. Guzman's puzzle page and noted one of the more remarkable Thursday puzzles I've ever seen. Had done this one, of course (as I imagine most of us had), but didn't entirely remember it. Anyway.... a Thursday from September 26, 2024. Hard to entirely describe this one, but I'll give it a shot. The 'reveal' in that one was a pair of answers across the very bottom of the puzzle: The clue (for the first answer): "With 63-Across, tricky football play ... as represented by this puzzle's shaded squares? " And those two answers: DOUBLE REVERSE And a pair of sample answers across the top of the puzzle with the 'shaded' squared in parentheses: Wonder drug : C(RU)E(LLA) Have the final turn : G(LO)A(TS) So... if you reverse the order of each of the shaded strings the answers become: CUREALL and GOLAST And there were more. A couple of other examples: S(ET)PO(IN)T becomes: STEPONIT and... TAR(NA)TI(ON) becomes: TARANTINO Pretty amazing. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=9/26/2024 ......

I struggled with this one. Solved it unaided, but took almost an hour. In part because Mario and I reside in different universes, so BOWSER and KOOPATROOPA were unknowns, with the latter being almost a random string of letters.

Not a fan of the grid design here, with the NW and SE barely connected to heart of the grid. Certainly this is helpful to the constructor, since it allows for modular construction. Note the very common letters SAN/SE  and AL/SES at the connection points. 

That said, there were only eight 3-letter entries here, and the six long central entries were solid enough. TOURDEFORCE and DAISYCHAINS nicely flanked the turtle-shelled flunky, and SANTATRACKER was interesting and cleverly clued. SEALEDTHEDEAL and CAMERALENSES were dull, but full of very common letters, which helps both the constructor and the solver. 

A solid Saturday debut, and a workout for me.

It really is a good deer-stalking aid!(In case you were wondering why Prancer ain't prancin no more.)

Hee hee. I sleigh me.

For those who might enjoy it, the Globe and Mail has published their giant Canada Day crossword. Subscribers only, but you can subscribe for a week for cheap. It‚Äôs a good chance to brush up on your Canadian content! (I‚Äôm not affiliated but look forward to this puzzle all year.)
I have accomplished the completion of this puzzle
That was tough. Got a lot of it but had to get help.

Great puzzle, Jesse! A bit scary last night when I was stuck with only a few guesses and spooked by Mario. (Video games are to me what Broadway musicals are to Andrzej, i.e., kryptonite.) When I waded back in at 5am somehow it was suddenly solvable. Whew! Looking forward to the one coming soon. I think.

Seeing a post from the legendary and lately elusive Puzzlemucker made this a special day indeed.

I got farther on this grid than I expected. 

Talking about contronyms, TABLE (7D) is one of them, and since Canadians go with the British meaning, that one stumped me. 

Aside from not knowing the Mario stuff, It didn't help that I fell yet again for the layer/layer trick. 

Agree with the objections below on MOONY and SOONEST.

Enjoyable Saturday puzzle, all in all.

Natick here with BOWSER/OCARINAS, but resolved with patience.

Fun figuring these things out with zero knowledge of so many entries.

Great puzzle.

Perhaps my favorite Saturday puzzle ever. Between BOWSER, RPG, and OCARINA it was quickly clear the constructor was a gamer, which bode well for my chances. And as a fellow gamer, it seemed like the constructor and I cliques in more ways than one.

Zero kludgey fill, wonderfully tricky clueing, and very little arcane trivia (outside of the Nintendo universe). The puzzle came together quicker than average as ah-ha moments came up at a rapid clip.

I get how this puzzle may not be for everyone, but I consider it a masterclass. Well done!

Well, Saturday NYT puzzles are supposed to be murky, dubious, and force people to expand the brains associations between words. 

And you‚Äôve done that. 

Well done.
So many wrong first answers. I love to just keep trying. Did have to look things up. This was a good one! Thanks!

So....Jesse Guzman goes up on the board after today's TOUR DE FORCE.  (I still don't get the clue; aren't 5 stars rather better?)

Not having a clue about Mario's foe or its sidekick left me in a serious fix when it came to this solve.  The number of gimmes was  minuscule!  BISTROS, KEEL, TABLE, and MAINE. RENO and RELIC teamed up with HERA, and then that little line dried up.
DAISY CROWN or CHAIN?  

I am likely one of the few here who has actually owned and played an  OCARINA...but don't go looking for it at the symphony.  It kind  of belongs in the kazoo family, being a bit of a whimsical toy instrument.  

How is MOONY crushing? 
How is DAWDLing (which does cost one time and tries the patience of others) related to "Kill[ing] time"(which is a deliberate use of excess time, and not necessarily wasteful)?
EONS would be hyperbole, not a metaphor.

Off to find the darts...
Incredibly fast for me, and I think I have to thank Nintendo for that. Getting 1A, 16D, and 2D instantly got things moving quickly. Fun puzzle, with 32A and 21A being a couple of my favorites.
Puzzles like this are why I keep coming back. What a satisfying solve!

I felt super good about this puzzle - half Saturday average, no look ups. A few hiccups. I had tales before TREKS and rein before RIDE.  And SARONG was a bit of a surprise, as I don't think I fancy a man in one - but what do I know.  Hehheh before HEEHEE, gotya before GOTEM. 
Fortunately my 1980s Nintendo knowledge didn't fail me. 
It was all in the part of the fun. Happy Saturday.

I'm reminded of one of the classiest and most eloquent of Jeopardy! champions, Sam Buttrey, who jokingly said to Alex, ‚ÄúI'll take stuff only old guys know for 400,‚Äù during a quarter final round.

This puzzle spoke to me as very generational, with a few familiar hints that we RELICS find satisfying.  (Tai Chi, Bill Withers, Hera and especially kelly).

The 18 Hungarian cases sent me on a quest and the results boggled my mind. I cannot even imagine what swims around in the mind of a linguistics major. I see enough music theory, algebra and beach scenes in my head to where I forget where I am.

So many of the constructors are young, I often wonder how many young people find solace in solving a good crossword puzzle. It must be difficult for them to relax with a crossword puzzle, with a career, a family, and all the distractions thrown at them.

This was a toughie! But tough in exactly the way I like a Saturday puzzle to be - minimal trivia, maximum pondering and penciling in. Looking forward to the next one Jesse!

"Unisex attire?" Well technically, yes, but with the caveat that only Samoan men look good in a SARONG. Skinny white dudes, not so much. You're trying too hard.

I'm not familiar with CELINE Dion's complete catalog, but I don't think there are any "power ballads" to be found. I don't remember a soaring guitar solo in "My Heart Will Go On." Prove me wrong.

Fine Saturday puzzle, though. Got off to a flying start with the Mario boss and his minions.

A huge thanks to Spelling Bee for one of the challenging Downs here! Keeping it vague to avoid a spoiler. That word was my single hold out to Queen Bee earlier this week, and I finally got it, thanks to Steve G‚Äôs hint (which also referenced a theme in today‚Äôs Crossword). It might otherwise have stumped me today, but jumped right out with a couple of crossing letters. Fun!

Loved this puzzle, in spite‚Äîor perhaps because‚Äîof the it‚Äôs difficulty for me.  I‚Äôve never played video games, but after the second cup of coffee my son helped with the turtle sidekick. The ‚ÄúP‚Äù gave me SOUPY and the rest of the dominoes fell easily after that. Thanks for a great Saturday morning!
Can someone please explain 40A to me.  How is MOONY crushing, in a way.  Solved it via crosses but don't understand the clue.

I loved all the Nintendo trivia and felt great about most of the grid, but then I got caught in the bottom right corner for about half an hour.

As for the stretchy clues, I felt very proud to get ‚ÄúSanta tracker‚Äù but wasn‚Äôt that sure about ‚Äúsoonest‚Äù even after I put it in.

Thanks for a fun puzzle!
Please explain 40 A. "Crushing, in a way" is Moony?
Reminds me of one of my favorite movies, "Ball of Fire"(1941), when the mailman is thrilled to hear the answer to one of the Quiz Clues, "Nobody's gonna get that".
Knowing nothing about Mario was a handicap, but ultimately not insurmountable!
Feel like I just got lucky with about 4 or 5 clues.

Breezed through this in just over ten minutes.  Being a lifelong gamer and Nintendo fan helped, but some of the clues I found questionable.

I always associated power ballads with hair metal bands, songs like ‚ÄúI‚Äôll Be There for You‚Äù by Bon Jovi, for example.  Celine had huge ballads, but they were mostly pop.  I know she did at least one Jim Steinman tune (‚ÄúIt‚Äôs All Coming Back to Me‚Äù), which I guess would count, but I never considered her a ‚Äúbig name‚Äù in power ballads.

Are deer and reindeer the same thing?  I figured out the reference easily enough but it got my suspicions up.

And the clue for SOONEST makes no sense whatsoever.

The OCARINA, also known as the Sweet Potato because of its potato like shape and sweet sound was used to great success by many composers - notably in the opening sequence of Bernardo Bertolucci's classic  film "1909", and Ennio Morricone''s score for "The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly".

I definitely needed Caitlin Lovinger's help with Kablooey and Santa tracker, neither of which seemed remotely connected to their respective clues. But overall, after applying the "this is going to be qwerky" to the clues, I whipped through this very interesting and intriguing puzzle. Well done Mr. Jesse Guzman, though I will need Ms. Lovinger if I do any future puzzles of yours. I don't mind. I enjoyed  working a  crossword that challenges my way of looking at things, and forces me to go for help. A true tour de force today.
I'm finally caught up on my crosswords this week, so will have lots of time to complete the Sunday one. Cheers y'all. Have a great week-end. ‚úåÔ∏è
I got SOONEST pretty quickly. The clue led my rat-brain to a scene in "Back to School" where Professor Barbay says something about there being two types of people in business: the quick and the dead.

Excellent Saturday puzzle that for me was by far the hardest in months. At the end I could not at first figure out why MOONY should be "Crushing, in a way" and waffled over that for too long until the penny dropped.

Loved the profusion of different words like IDYLLS, SARONG, ASTERISK, ANGELICA (which I hadn't heard of despite spending many years in California), and especially KABLOOEY.

Thought the clues for SANTA TRACKER and CAMERA LENSES, among others, were terrific. Had a big Doh! moment after seeing the clue "Record qualifier" and thinking "What word(s) could mean asterisk?" until the light finally dawned. 

I could have done without *two* clues about the same obscure-to-me Marioverse (BOWSER could be clued as a traditional dog's name). But all in all, it's a great feeling when a puzzle seems nigh-impossible at first and then fingerhold by fingerhold and toehold by toehold becomes possible. The longer it takes, the more fun I have! One of my favorite Saturday puzzles in a long time.

Several times recently, I've had one square remaining with two possible letters to fill it.  That's kind of new for me, but could create a quandary if I let it. Do I research one of the possible answers, or take a guess and wait for music/no music? Unlike some here, I decline to invalidate my streak either way. The software is kind and lets me guess, so I do. 

(When I used to fill these out in pencil, if I missed a 50/50 guess I would probably have marked it wrong. Would not have affected my streak, which was a consistent zero.)

Like many, I am a stranger to the Marvel Universe and figured the most probable name for the turtle-shelled flunky would start with an 's' but the most probable onomatopoeia for shot would start with a 'K.'

Hesitated for awhile to enter "SOONEST." I can make it fit the clue, but only by a stretch, so I suspect I still haven't quite gotten the sense of it. I'll read the comments later because I'm sure someone has. All of the other answers fit their clues quite cleanly, to my mind.

Like Caitlin and many other commenters, I associate 80s hair bands with power ballads.

Which led to a fun round of playing power ballads at each other.

Boy, the mention of the Peppermill brings back memories. For some reason, they used to have a restaurant in Cupertino, right next to Apple's HQ. (The pre-spaceship Apple campus.) No casino, of course, but the waitresses dressed in skimpy outfits like they were in one. It was very strange.

Well, after making good progress solving weekend puzzles with few or no lookups, this one made me feel like a beginner again. But the southwest corner had only one fact clue, and Dr. Google could not come up with Angelica as a sweet California wine.  So I got there with check answers and autocheck. Overall, I liked this puzzle and thought most of the clues were written well. Since the constructor notes specifically call them out, I thought [Deer stalking aid?] was clever and fun, but I still can't really make sense of SOONEST for [Most likely to succeed?]

I think I get that "succeed" is referring to things happening in succession, and the next soonest thing is the one that will succeed, or take the place of, the current one. But if we already know it is the next soonest thing, the qualifier *most likely* doesn't make sense to me--how could anything else happen before the next soonest thing? 

I think this clue would have done much better if it were about succeeding a throne. I in fact briefly considered filling in SONN-EST as being the most likely candidate for patrilineal succession before I figured out the cross.

Overall, though, I liked the puzzle, and that was one of my only gripes. If anyone has a better explanation, I'm all ears!

@Jerry

As I said, country music is an amalgam of many musical styles.  Some of the other sources include West Africa, from which the banjo came, the Mediterranean, which gave it the guitar and mandolin, and the creole/Cajun instrumentation of the Mississippi delta.

Many people bristled when several Black artists, led by Beyonce, made inroads into commercial country music in the past year or two.  They said that country was a purely white form of music, and that there were plenty of Black musical styles already.

Those people were quite wrong; before recorded music and the industry's penchant for categorizing and separating genres by race, most southern rural music in the US was performed by people of all skin tones, and fit into the same genral genre.
